description: Shows names of counties, major cities and towns, and rivers. Title, date, and scale from Stephenson's Civil War maps, 1989. Pen-and-ink on tracing linen, mounted on cloth. Stamped in green ink in top left corner: Excelsior linen cloth. LC Civil War maps (2nd ed.), H201 Available also through the Library of Congress web site as raster image. On verso partially obscured by mounting: Unpublished tracings of states and counties, prepared for the purpose of illustrating proposed report of Jed. Hotchkiss on the geology of all states and countries represented in the mines and mining exhibits at the Columbian Exposition, 1893. In pencil on verso: 214.

medium: 1 ms. map : cloth ; 35 x 27 cm., on sheet 51 x 60 cm.

description: Shows the advance of the French Napoleonic forces eastward from Dantzick (Gdańsk, Poland) to Smolensk (Russia) by 21 August 1812. Indicates the French and Russian army troop positions and movements in what is now Poland, Lithuania, Belarus, and Russia. No statement of attribution or date of publication are present. Title from upper margin. No handwritten signature of Millard Fillmore is present (recto or verso). When affixed to the cloth backing the map sheet was sectioned to 6 panels to enable folding. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. LC sheet imperfect: Recto darkened at sheet edges and at panel intervals, lightly water-stained; cloth backing water-stained and sunlight-darkened; LC acquision rubber-stamping on recto in lower margin. Includes text, bar scale "Échelle en lieues de 25 au degré", and note "Distances de Dantzick à Smolensk et à Moskou". Handwritten (script) title slip affixed to cloth backing (verso): Map of the War of 1812 in Europe; number label affixed to cloth backing; 240. Vault

medium: 1 map : color, mounted on cloth backing ; 30 x 41 cm
notes: Shows the advance of the French Napoleonic forces eastward from Dantzick (Gdańsk, Poland) to Smolensk (Russia) by 21 August 1812.

description: Relief shown by contours, hachures and spot heights. Japanese title and annotations in red and blue pencil, map drawn in black pen-and-ink. English title and annotations in red pencil and black pen-and-ink. Map shows the name of each regiment, its location and area of responsibility, along with its boundaries, and depicts road conditions and positions. Map was probably drawn by the Japanese Navy and later added translation and annotations by the U.S. Army. In Japanese and English. The Japanese Navy stationed its first garrison on Pohnpei Island in 1940, followed by a full-fledged guard in 1942, after the outbreak of the Pacific War. The U.S. military attacked Pohnpei Island on February 15, 1944, and continued through May. Seal of possession of the Japanese Navy or Army General Staff on map. Torn at fold lines. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. vcFY24

notes: Relief shown by contours, hachures and spot heights.
Japanese title and annotations in red and blue pencil, map drawn in black pen-and-ink. English title and annotations in red pencil and black pen-and-ink.
Map shows the name of each regiment, its location and area of responsibility, along with its boundaries, and depicts road conditions and positions.
Map was probably drawn by the Japanese Navy and later added translation and annotations by the U.S. Army.
In Japanese and English.

The Japanese Navy stationed its first garrison on Pohnpei Island in 1940, followed by a full-fledged guard in 1942, after the outbreak of the Pacific War. The U.S. military attacked Pohnpei Island on February 15, 1944, and continued through May.
Seal of possession of the Japanese Navy or Army General Staff on map. Torn at fold lines.
Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.
